Comment: The French Defense, which can leave Black with good prospects if played well, or a horribly cramped game if, as in this case, it is played badly.

Giving up the center too easily.
Giving up the center too easily.
I prefer a developmental system of B-K2, N-KB3 and O-O for Black in this position. Followed up by N-Q2 so as to recapture on KB3 with a Knight, this system keeps Black's King safe.
I prefer a developmental system of B-K2, N-KB3 and O-O for Black in this position. Followed up by N-Q2 so as to recapture on KB3 with a Knight, this system keeps Black's King safe.
Weakening. The natural spot for the N is KB3, especially if K-side castling is in the works. it provides much better defense from KB3.
Weakening. The natural spot for the N is KB3, especially if K-side castling is in the works. it provides much better defense from KB3.
White exploits the weakend Black K-side with a pin.
If Black's B were on K2 and his N on KB3, this move would be acceptable. Instead, White rips away Black's flimsy defenses.
If Black tries 7... K-R1 here, 8 Q-R5! is a deadly stroke. Note that if Black's N were at KB3, White would have to exchange off his own N to get ...Q-R5 in.
The King-hunt begins. Black is in dire straits.

Black prepares to guard 9 Q-N4 ch with 9...N-N3. But...
There is no defense. Mate is now forced.
As is so often the case, this move is deadly.
